caption: Place de la Bastille is a significant historical square in Paris, known for its rich history and lively atmosphere. Originally the site of the notorious Bastille prison, its liberation on July 14, 1789, marked the beginning of the French Revolution. Today, the square features the impressive July Column, commemorating those who fought for freedom.  Surrounded by bustling cafes, shops, and cultural venues, Place de la Bastille is a hub of activity. Visitors can enjoy a leisurely stroll, take in the sights, and immerse themselves in the vibrant local culture. The nearby Bastille Market offers a delightful selection of fresh produce, artisanal goods, and local delicacies, perfect for a casual afternoon outing.  In the evenings, the square transforms into a lively gathering place, with outdoor seating at cafes and bars, making it an ideal spot for enjoying a drink and people-watching. Whether you’re interested in history, shopping, or simply soaking in the Parisian vibe, Place de la Bastille is a must-visit destination that beautifully combines the past with the present.
It's pretty open it's a walk by attraction it's free. There is also a small skateboard park near by used by locals
Wonderful open area full of historical significance. Has public seating. Many police and military on patrol for Olympics. Don’t miss the picture with the Olympic rings.

Place de La Bastille is a must-visit location in Paris, rich in history and vibrant with life. The square is not only a symbol of the French Revolution but also a hub of activity where past and present seamlessly blend. The iconic July Column stands tall in the center, offering a perfect spot for photos.  Whether you're strolling through the area or enjoying a coffee at a nearby café, the energy of the place is contagious. The surrounding streets are full of charming shops and restaurants, making it a great spot to explore. Plus, the proximity to the beautiful Bastille Opera House adds a cultural touch to the visit.  Overall, Place de La Bastille is a perfect mix of history, culture, and modern Parisian life. I highly recommend adding it to your itinerary when visiting Paris!

Place de la Bastille is rich in history and has a unique atmosphere, but my experience was somewhat dampened—perhaps due to the bad weather. Despite the clouds, it’s clear this square has a lot to offer with its lively surroundings and historical significance. On a sunnier day, I’m sure it would be even more impressive. A solid four-star spot to explore in Paris.

Sure, there are some shops and cafes nearby, but nothing really stood out or made me want to stick around for long. The waterfront nearby is where it's really nice.

Place de la Bastille is a historically significant and vibrant square in Paris. With its rich history as a symbol of the French Revolution, it is not only a practical hub for relaxation but also an emblematic space that resonates with the spirit of liberty. Surrounded by an array of inviting bars, restaurants, and cafes, it provides a charming backdrop for a leisurely evening. As you unwind amidst the lively atmosphere, take a moment to appreciate the historical significance of the July Column and the remnants of the Bastille fortress. The fusion of modern-day amenities and historical resonance makes it a truly unique and enriching place to chill on both weekday and weekend evenings.

Place de la Bastille is a square in Paris, a symbolic place of the French Revolution, where the old Bastille citadel was destroyed. In the middle of the square is the July Column. This column is not linked to the French Revolution of 1789, but rather to the revolution of 1830 that took place over three days, known as the “Three Glorious Days.” This revolutionary episode led to the fall of the Restoration regime, the establishment of the July Monarchy, the dismissal of King Charles His cousin, King Louis Philippe I.  This column is therefore a monument in honor of the Parisian Rebellion which has not changed much since one member of the royal family succeeded another member of the royal family.  This monument, erected in a revolutionary place, is a revolutionary symbol that carries the message of freedom, and an angel is placed at its top called the “Angel of Freedom.”

Good place to chill on a weekday or weekend evenings after work. There are many bars, restaurants, cafe’s and few supermarkets nearby. If you love skating, then you can find an arena where people are freestyling with their boards
Great place full of history. Had the Olympic rings!

Worth visiting the historic place.

The Place de la Bastille is a historic square in Paris, France, known as the site of the Bastille prison, which played a significant role in French history, particularly during the French Revolution. On July 14, 1789, the storming of the Bastille marked a pivotal moment, symbolizing the uprising against the monarchy and the beginning of the French Revolution. This event is celebrated annually in France as Bastille Day.  Today, the Bastille prison no longer stands, as it was demolished shortly after the Revolution. Instead, the square is marked by the Colonne de Juillet (July Column), a monumental column topped with a gilded statue known as the “Génie de la Liberté” (Spirit of Freedom). This column commemorates the Revolution of 1830, which led to the July Monarchy.  The Place de la Bastille is a lively cultural and social hub, surrounded by cafés, shops, and the modern Opéra Bastille, one of Paris’s main opera houses. The area is a popular meeting place for locals and tourists alike and is often the site of gatherings, protests, and events, holding onto its legacy as a place of revolution and public expression.
We saw the Place de la Bastille from the streets but we liked the view when it was dark. With the lights, the Place de la Bastille looks beautiful.
A very historically important place in Paris and France. As a French history enthusiast, I was very impressed by the grandeur and splendour of the monument.
Good place to relax, not really crowded and with lots of places for coffee/drink around. Good located next to a tube station. It was an exhibition in the square when we were there.

His historic location has so much going for it to visit...the Bastille Opera House, a market experience on Thursday and Sundays, many restaurants, a great location to meet friends and nearby streets to stroll for events..
This proud column dedicated to the revolution of 1830, is the centre piece of Place de la Bastille, the site of the Fortress Bastille.
Better go there at night or clear day, good view and a lot of places to drink and eat. Don't miss the nearby river.
